Award.AwardTitle: Dissertation Research: Species delimitation and the evolution of dwarfism in the North American tarantula genus Aphonopelma
Award.AbstractNarration:
The tarantula genus Aphonopelma ranks among the most infamous mygalomorph spiders (tarantulas, trapdoor spiders and their kin) of the American southwest, yet they are a group that has been woefully understudied because traditional morphological characters are generally ineffective at consistently and rigorously identifying species boundaries. Widely distributed throughout the southwestern United States and Mexico, many Aphonopelma species reside within two biodiversity ?hotspots?: the California Floristic Province and the Madrean pine-oak woodlands in Arizona. It is of critical importance that we discover and develop methods to accurately identify the species-level diversity within the group before it is lost to extinction. Our project will integrate "Anchored Enrichment" genomic data, from high-throughput next-generation sequencing, with geospatial analyses to resolve species boundaries within Aphonopelma, while investigating the evolution of miniaturization and subsequent diversification in a very unique lineage of dwarf tarantula species.

Data generated from this project will substantially increase the molecular markers currently available for species delimitation in spiders. This will be the first study to employ this cutting edge genomic approach in any spider group. Project activities will provide training in modern phylogenetic and bioinformatics techniques, taxonomic, and organismal expertise to undergraduates from underrepresented groups in science, while broadening international collaboration with graduate students in Mexico and other parts of the world.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The discovery of species provides the crucial first-step in the ongoing pursuit to understand the evolutionary patterns and processes shaping Earth's biodiversity landscape. With over 250 years of taxonomic work behind us, ~1.2 million species have been described - with an estimated 7-10 million species on Earth still remaining to be described. Unfortunately, species are disappearing at an alarming rate, often without even being known to science, complicating our view of the Tree of Life.

            Tarantulas arguably comprise the most speciose lineage within the spider infraorder Mygalomorphae (the trapdoor, funnel-web, and tarantula spiders). The tarantula genus Aphonopelma ranks among the most infamous residents of the American southwest, yet they are a group that has been woefully understudied because traditional morphological characters are generally ineffective at consistently and rigorously identifying species boundaries. This morphological homogeneity has led to great frustration when attempting to understand evolutionary patterns and processes that shaped one of Earth's most diverse lineages of tarantula. By conducting the most comprehensive sampling of a single tarantula genus to date, this research significantly broadens the scope of prior molecular and morphological investigations, finally bringing a modern understanding of the true species diversity in this dynamic and charismatic group of spiders - in particular the multiple species distributed throughout two biodiversity hotspots in the United States (i.e., California Floristic Province and Madrean Pine-Oak Woodlands), and those comprising the unique miniature Aphonopelma.

            Inferring evolutionary relationships among groups of organisms is one of the fundamental objectives of systematic biology. The principal goal of this research was to formally resolve the group’s species-level diversity by integrating genomic data with novel morphological investigations, and geospatial analyses. One primary goal was to generate a phylogenomic probe set, using Anchored Enrichment (AE), that would substantially increase the molecular data currently available for spiders - this is the first study to employ this unique genomic approach in spiders. Another goal was to provide training in modern phylogenetic and bioinformatics techniques, taxonomic, and organismal expertise to an undergraduate and graduate student within underrepresented groups in science, while broadening international collaboration with fellow graduate students in Mexico. To fulfill this, our research provided training in taxonomic and organismal expertise, while broadening participation of underrepresented groups in science – coPI Hamilton (Native American), Xavier Atkinson (undergraduate East Carolina University), and Miranda Reich (undergraduate Auburn University). The project also broadened international collaboration by working together with fellow graduate students in Mexico (UNAM) by aiding them in the implementation of molecular methodologies to their research. As part of community outreach, Auburn University has opened a new Natural History Museum & Biodiversity Learning Center. Working through the new natural history museum, we have engaged the public by teaching spider biology to 1st – 8th grade students and their parents as part of the GUTS (Getting Under the Surface) program, AU Explore (expanding biological understanding in our local school systems), as well as the Summer Science Institute, and have participated in the undergraduate Freshman Conservation Biology Learning Community.
